bestBHT.bht: In a moment of caprice, the king, though called so only by courtesy, made a reckless oath to Salome, a young girl of marriageable age. This impulsive act, resembling the oath Ahasuerus made to Esther, demonstrates the regret that often follows when self-control is lost to passion and luxury. The subsequent marriage of Salome to Philip the Tetrarch further emphasizes the consequences of indulging in unchecked desires. Let this narrative serve as a cautionary tale, reminding us of the dangers of hasty words and the importance of temperance.

bhtAttempts.bht: In a capricious moment, the king, only known as such by courtesy, made a boastful oath to the young girl, Salome, promising her anything she desired, up to half of his kingdom. Such reckless words are often regretted in moments of cool reflection, as passion and luxury can cloud one's self-command. This reminds one of a similar oath made by Ahasuerus to his queen Esther. Despite the context, Salome's marriage to Philip the Tetrarch is mentioned, highlighting the consequences of impulsive actions. May this passage serve as a cautionary example of the dangers of unchecked desires and rash words.

In a capricious moment, the king, called so only by courtesy, rashly swore an oath to Salome, a young girl of marriageable age. This boastful declaration, reminiscent of Ahasuerus' oath to Esther, highlights the regret that often follows impulsive actions fueled by passion and luxury. The mention of Salome's subsequent marriage to Philip the Tetrarch further emphasizes the consequences of such unchecked desires. Let this serve as a stark reminder of the perils of hasty words and the importance of self-control.
